title: Front Brake Master Cylinder Hose Inlet - Removal

body.body: Front Brake Master Cylinder Hose Inlet - Removal
Before starting work, ensure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported. This will help prevent it from falling and causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Caution - do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork. Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Drain the fluid from the master cylinder by bleeding the system at the rear brake caliper until all fluid has been expelled.
Release the fixing and detach the brake fluid reservoir bracket from the master cylinder.
Disconnect the brake fluid reservoir hose from the master cylinder and remove the brake fluid reservoir.
Do not operate the front brake lever.
Operating the front brake lever with the fluid reservoir disconnected will allow air to enter the brake system.
A brake system containing air reduces braking efficiency and may cause loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Note the orientation of the hose inlet prior to removing it from the master cylinder.
In some instances the grommet may remain located in the aperture of the master cylinder.
With the aid of an assistant to support the handlebars, loosen the hose inlet by moving from side to side whilst pulling and remove the hose inlet assembly from the master cylinder.
Never lever directly against the brake master cylinder as this will damage these components. Always use a levering tool made from a soft material which will not cause damage to the machined surfaces.
Remove the grommet from the master cylinder.

metadata.products: NN6; NN5; DD2; NN4; NN3; HD6; HBM; HB; HB2; DE2
